content: If you copied profile from old pc to new using this process: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer then the passwords would also have transferred, and would work if the passwords were not 'app' passwords. I share that for any future similar instances. Although there is no setup for a password change, if the password is failing, you should see a prompt to enter a new one. If the account is POP, the messages do transfer when using the above URL process. To force a prompt, you could go to settings>privacy&security, click savedpasswords and then showpasswords and then highlight the rows for that account and delete them.
creator: davidsk

content: If you are receiving error message for wrong password, then see your email provider for a new one. The password that you may have previously stored in thunderbird is not working.
creator: davidsk

content: It depends. Some email providers, such as Gmail, require an 'app' password that is unique to each PC, while others use the same password everywhere. My general advice is this: when setting up an account DO NOT enter the password until first request for messages and you receive a prompt for it. In most instances, if an app password is required, the email provider will accept your password and will then store a special password for the PC. If an app password is not required, the normal password itself will be accepted and stored on the PC.
creator: davidsk

content:
Step 1: Check Basic Filter Settings Go to Tools > Message Filters.

Ensure the filters are applied to the correct account (POP inbox).

Try setting the filter to run "Manually" and test it by selecting an email and clicking "Run Now".

Step 2: Verify Folder Permissions Check if Inbox and other mail folders are not corrupted.

Right-click the Inbox > Properties > Repair Folder.

Step 3: Delete & Recreate Filters Navigate to Message Filters.

Delete all filters (if they are corrupted).

Create a new test filter (e.g., move messages from a certain sender to a folder).

Run the filter manually to see if it works.

Step 4: Reset Thunderbird's Filter File Close Thunderbird.

Go to:

Mac: ~/Library/Thunderbird/Profiles/your_profile.default/Mail/pop_account/

Find the file msgFilterRules.dat.

Rename it to msgFilterRules.old (backup).

Restart Thunderbird and recreate filters manually.

Step 5: Check Thunderbird Version & Update Go to Help > About Thunderbird and ensure you’re running the latest stable version.

If issues started after an update, consider downgrading to an older, stable version.

Step 6: Test in Safe Mode Start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode (Safe Mode):

Hold the Option key while opening Thunderbird.

Click "Continue in Troubleshoot Mode".

Test if filters work here.

Step 7: Consider Moving to IMAP If POP is unreliable, consider switching to IMAP, which syncs emails better and has fewer corruption issues.

If the issue persists, I’d recommend filing a bug report with Thunderbird’s team (Bugzilla for Thunderbird) or checking their official forums.
creator: usatube15

content:
In base al messaggio di errore che si vede nello screenshot, è il server di Alice che chiude la connessione.

Una delle cause più comuni segnalata anche da altri utenti è l'uso di una connessione non TIM. In ogni caso è come TIM che dovresti parlare, non sembra un problema di Thunderbird. Ovviamente sto dando per scontato che tu abbia configurato correttamente l'account.
